name: hc_stressor_cascade_boss
description: [HC] Hospital rooftop kitchen marine + GDC-FLEX RF 600x600 3000â†’MULTI-BLOCK
query: Rooftop kitchen exhaust for a hospital. Marine climate. 3000 mÂ³/h. We want GDC-FLEX RF 600x600.

turns.content: Rooftop kitchen exhaust for a hospital. Marine climate. 3000 mÂ³/h. We want GDC-FLEX RF 600x600.

For the rooftop kitchen exhaust at the hospital, the requested GDC-FLEX housing is blocked due to installation and capacity constraints. The GDC-FLEX is not rated for marine environments and its rail-mounted construction does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine installation. Additionally, the requested airflow of 3000 mÂ³/h exceeds the maximum capacity of 1750 mÂ³/h for a single 600x600 module. The system is also exposed to High Humidity, Chemical Vapor Exposure, Outdoor Condensation, Grease/Oil Exposure, Salt Spray, and Hygiene Requirements. Salt spray accelerates corrosion of the C2-rated housing, while marine/coastal environments require C5.1 marine-grade corrosion resistance. Outdoor condensation on non-insulated metal surfaces necessitates a double-wall insulated housing. High humidity reduces carbon adsorption efficiency. Grease/Oil Exposure will cause lipids to permanently coat activated carbon pores, deactivating the carbon. A pre-filter stage is mandatory for any application where grease, oil, or fat is present in the airstream. Gas/odor/VOC removal requires activated carbon adsorption.Unfortunately, no standard catalog product satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for marine environments, provide double-wall insulation, and include a grease separator. I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.To address the Grease/Oil Exposure and provide carbon filtration, a two-stage assembly is required:

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identified multiple critical failures in the user's request: the airflow exceeded the product's capacity, the product is rated for indoor use only while the user requested rooftop installation, and the application (kitchen exhaust) requires pre-filtration to protect the carbon. The refusal to recommend the specific product was technically sound and backed by catalog data.

dimension_explanations.correctness: Correctly identified that GDC FLEX 600x600 has a max capacity of 1750 mÂ³/h (PDF p.16), which is far below the requested 3000 mÂ³/h.
dimension_explanations.completeness: Addressed all aspects: capacity, environmental suitability (marine/outdoor), material corrosion, and application safety (grease).
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly flagged the risk of grease fouling activated carbon and the corrosion risk of using a C2-rated product in a marine environment.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, explaining the engineering reasons for the block.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Excellent logic chain connecting the 'kitchen' application to grease risks and the 'outdoor/marine' location to insulation and corrosion requirements.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Strictly adhered to the 'FÃ¶r inomhusbruk' (Indoor use) constraint listed on PDF p.16.

strengths: Accurate capacity verification against PDF data (1750 vs 3000 mÂ³/h)
Strong domain knowledge regarding kitchen exhaust filtration (grease vs. carbon)
Correct identification of environmental constraints (Indoor vs. Marine Rooftop)

GDC FLEX: 'FÃ¶r inomhusbruk' (For indoor use) (PDF p.16)
GDC FLEX: Standard material is FZ/C2 (PDF p.16)

openai.explanation: The system correctly identified that the requested GDC-FLEX 600x600 cannot handle 3000 mÂ³/h in a single module and appropriately warned about grease pre-filtration needs. However, it introduced non-catalog constraints (marine/hygiene/leakage-class/rail-mounted) and over-blocked without selecting viable catalog-based alternatives (e.g., multiple modules, material options), reducing correctness and constraint adherence.

dimension_explanations.correctness: PDF confirms GDC FLEX 600x600 has recommended flow 1750 mÂ³/h (so 3000 mÂ³/h exceeds one module), but claims about GDC-FLEX not being marine-rated/rail-mounted and not meeting leakage/hygiene classes are not supported by the provided catalog and some humidity/carbon-efficiency statements are overgeneralized.
dimension_explanations.completeness: It did not progress to a feasible configuration (e.g., 2x 600x600 modules or a larger GDC size) nor ask key clarifications like required carbon contact time/removal target, duct orientation, or acceptable multi-module bank.
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly flags grease/oil exposure as incompatible with direct carbon use and calls for mandatory pre-filtration/grease separation for kitchen exhaust, which is an important protection and fire/maintenance risk consideration.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional, consultative, and appropriately cautious for a hospital rooftop exhaust context.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Good capacity check and cause-effect on grease fouling, but the reasoning jumps to 'no standard product' based on unsupported environment/leakage/hygiene assertions and does not show a structured alternative sizing path.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: It correctly enforced the catalog capacity constraint for 600x600 GDC FLEX, but it treated material/environment limitations as hard blocks without citing catalog support (catalog lists multiple materials generally and does not state marine/outdoor prohibition as a product rule).

strengths: Correctly identified the airflow capacity mismatch for the requested 600x600 GDC FLEX module
Appropriately highlighted grease/oil fouling risk and the need for pre-filtration in kitchen exhaust applications
weaknesses: Introduced unsupported constraints (marine rating, rail-mounted, leakage class/hygiene compliance) not evidenced in the provided PDF
Failed to propose catalog-feasible alternatives (multi-module, larger sizes, or material upgrades) and did not ask clarifying questions to converge on a solution
pdf_citations: GDC FLEX 600x600: Rek. flÃ¶de 1750 mÂ³/h (catalog table under GDC FLEX 'MÃ…TT')
GDC (non-FLEX) 600x600: Rek. flÃ¶de 2000 mÂ³/h (catalog table under GDC 'MÃ…TT')

anthropic.explanation: The system correctly identified multiple critical constraints: GDC FLEX 600x600 has a max capacity of 1750 mÂ³/h (PDF confirms this), the housing is rated C2 which is inadequate for marine C5 environments, and grease in kitchen exhaust will foul activated carbon. The block is justified. The response is comprehensive in listing all environmental hazards but could have been more proactive in suggesting specific alternative configurations or a multi-module approach.

dimension_explanations.correctness: GDC FLEX 600x600 Rek. flÃ¶de = 1750 mÂ³/h (PDF p.16 confirms), and the C2 corrosion rating for standard FZ is correct per PDF p.14; the claim that RF (stainless) is available for GDC FLEX is supported by the material icons on p.16, though the system's mention of C5.1 marine-grade requirement is sound engineering but SF (acid-proof stainless, C5.1) would be the specific material needed.
dimension_explanations.completeness: The response covers airflow mismatch, material unsuitability, grease pre-filtration, humidity effects on carbon, outdoor condensation, and hygiene requirements, but does not offer a concrete alternative product configuration or multi-housing arrangement.
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly identifies all critical risks: grease fouling of carbon, salt spray corrosion on C2 housing, outdoor condensation on single-wall housing, and hygiene requirements for hospital applications â€” all appropriate blocks.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, though the dense listing of all environmental hazards could be better organized for readability; the recommendation to contact custom engineering is appropriate.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Clear cause-effect chains are provided for each constraint (salt spray â†’ corrosion, grease â†’ carbon fouling, outdoor â†’ condensation), though the reasoning could be more explicit about why no standard product works and what the closest viable option would be.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Correctly blocks the configuration due to multiple hard constraints: airflow exceeds capacity, material rating insufficient for marine environment, single-wall construction unsuitable for outdoor/rooftop, and grease pre-filtration requirement.

strengths: Accurately identifies the airflow capacity mismatch (3000 mÂ³/h requested vs. 1750 mÂ³/h max for GDC FLEX 600x600)
Comprehensive identification of all environmental hazards including grease fouling, salt spray corrosion, condensation risk, and hygiene requirements for hospital applications
weaknesses: Does not suggest a concrete alternative configuration (e.g., larger GDC FLEX size like 900x600 at 2500 mÂ³/h or multi-module arrangement, paired with appropriate material upgrade)
The response ends with a truncated two-stage assembly mention and a '[WARNING: Blocked]' tag without fully explaining what the two stages would be, reducing actionability

GDC FLEX material options shown as FZ, AZ, RF, SF, ZM (PDF p.16 material icons)
GDC FLEX standard corrosion class C2 for FZ (PDF p.16), RF = C5 per material page (PDF p.4)

content_segments.text: For the rooftop kitchen exhaust at the hospital, the requested GDC-FLEX housing is blocked due to installation and capacity constraints.

The GDC-FLEX is not rated for marine environments and its rail-mounted construction does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine installation. Additionally, the requested airflow of 3000 mÂ³/h exceeds the maximum capacity of 1750 mÂ³/h for a single 600x600 module.
The system is also exposed to High Humidity, Chemical Vapor Exposure, Outdoor Condensation, Grease/Oil Exposure, Salt Spray, and Hygiene Requirements.

Salt spray accelerates corrosion of the C2-rated housing, while marine/coastal environments require C5.1 marine-grade corrosion resistance. Outdoor condensation on non-insulated metal surfaces necessitates a double-wall insulated housing. High humidity reduces carbon adsorption efficiency. Grease/Oil Exposure will cause lipids to permanently coat activated carbon pores, deactivating the carbon. A pre-filter stage is mandatory for any application where grease, oil, or fat is present in the airstream. Gas/odor/VOC removal requires activated carbon adsorption.

Unfortunately, no standard catalog product satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for marine environments, provide double-wall insulation, and include a grease separator. I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.
To address the Grease/Oil Exposure and provide carbon filtration, a two-stage assembly is required:
